Chang and I'm Ari Shapiro many people in the U.S auto industry are breathing a sigh of relief this week the new trade deal between the U.S Mexico and Canada and months of uncertainty if it's approved by Congress it will spare carmakers from some of the terrorists that they had feared
And will soon as senior vice president of the motor and equipment Manufacturers Association which represents more than a thousand companies that make auto parts you're in the U.S thanks for joining us here on all things considered thank you very glad to be with you to begin with what you just described for listeners what you remember companies making and where you are in the auto making supply chain
So our members make the vast majority of the content for new vehicles and we also manufacture parts and components for maintenance and repair
And how much was on the line for you in this trade agreement ... holding your breath to see what the details would be

So we are very pleased relieved to that all three parties were able to come to an agreement this weekend we're cautiously optimistic that the terms of the agreement will work for the industry and for the American public
When you look at the details of the agreement can you tell how it compares to NAFTA for you
Well there's going to be an increase in the amount of North American content that will be required
For parts to travel through the three countries going to have to call it the U.S Mexico Canada agreement but she traveled through North America without having to pay tariffs there's going to be a requirement for more North American steel and aluminum us so all of that were impact our members
And in addition there's going to be some new administrative costs that are going to be required one of the concerns we have though are there some new tariffs out there right now on steel and aluminum and we'd like to see Canada and the United states address that before they finalized disagreement in the end of November
So on the one hand there won't be terrorists for material crossing Canada U.S Mexico border is on the other hand the steel and aluminum tariffs that were of concern to your industry have not gone away
No they have and I think one of the things we have the mind as they have been a particular burden to smaller manufacturers many of these smaller manufacturers are only in the U.S
And some of our members have seen the cost of their steel purchases rise almost fifty percent
So this is a significant increase it's typically is concerned between Canada and the United states we'd like to see those two countries roll up their sleeves used his fame energy they use to conclude this this new NAFTA and be able to come to some kind of agreement on steel and aluminum tariffs
I Know that there's a lot of relief from the auto industry now that the uncertainty is gone but how does this compare to the old rules under NAFTA isn't an improvement is is it worse well
I think from the United states perspective one of the things in the United states said little pool through was an increase in the U.S content and for some of our suppliers and some component manufacturers this is going to be a challenge there is no doubt about that
I Do think that we're going to see more Fillmore aluminum that's from North America in our vehicles the biggest concern our members are going to have
